channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Forces' charity axes NoW campaign
item.description: The Royal British Legion suspends links with the News of the World amid claims the paper may have hacked the phones of bereaved military families.

item.title: Slave police inquiries 'flawed'
item.description: Three police investigations involving a Bedfordshire man who was murdered, decapitated and dumped in a lake were "flawed", the police watchdog says.

item.title: Man guilty of trafficking girls
item.description: A man becomes the first person to be found guilty of trafficking females out of the UK, in a case involving two Nigerian teenage girls.

item.title: UK interest rates remain at 0.5%
item.description: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee has kept UK interest rates on hold at a record low of 0.5%.

item.title: Real IRA chief loses Omagh appeal
item.description: Real IRA leader Michael McKevitt loses his appeal against a landmark civil case which held him liable for the 1998 Omagh bombing.

item.title: UK holds Spain king plot suspect
item.description: A Spanish man has been arrested in the UK on suspicion of an attempted assassination of the king of Spain in 1997, British police say.

item.title: Fear over aircraft carrier change
item.description: The National Audit Office expresses concern about changes to the Royal Navy's two new aircraft carriers made in the 2010 defence review.

item.title: Code 'covered UK troops in Iraq'
item.description: UK troops accused of unlawful killing civilians during the Iraq war were governed by Europe's human rights code, judges in Strasbourg rule.

item.title: Japan nuclear checks criticised
item.description: The Japanese government's plan to hold further safety tests on nuclear plants before reopening them is denounced by local officials and critics.

item.title: Yellowstone grizzly kills hiker
item.description: A female grizzly bear kills a man in the US hiking with his wife in Yellowstone National Park after the couple apparently surprised the bear and its cubs.

item.title: Harry Potter fans drenched in premiere vigil
item.description: Thousands of Harry Potter fans are braving wet weather in London's Trafalgar Square, ahead of the world premiere of the final film in the series.

item.title: The lake that really is a village green
item.description: A 50-acre lake at Llanfaelog on Anglesey is given village green status as the community council strives to protect it as a local amenity.

item.title: Modric 'will not hand in request'
item.description: Luka Modric has no plans to hand in a transfer request at Tottenham, according to his agent Nikky Vuksan.

item.title: Sportsday Live - breaking sports news as it happens
item.description: Tottenham's Luka Modric will not hand in transfer request, says agent

item.title: Ricky Hatton announces retirement
item.description: Former welterweight and light-welterweight world champion Ricky Hatton announces his retirement at the age of 32.

item.title: Liverpool line up new Downing bid
item.description: Liverpool are thought to be preparing a new bid for Aston Villa's Stewart Downing after the rejection of their initial £15m offer.

item.title: Man Utd still in hunt for Nasri
item.description: Manchester United remain hopeful of signing Samir Nasri after making a near-£20m bid for Arsenal's French international midfielder.

item.title: Argyle chairman 'e-mails hacked'
item.description: Plymouth Argyle's acting chairman Peter Ridsdale confirms he is suing the News of the World over hacking claims.

item.title: Man sat on violent Ryanair flyer
item.description: A passenger who restrained an "aggressive and violent" man on a Marrakesh-to-Bristol flight speaks about his experience.

item.title: Probe into Sheridan case evidence
item.description: Witness statements at the Tommy Sheridan perjury trial are to be probed following new allegations in the News of the World hacking scandal.

item.title: Police inquiry after body found
item.description: Detectives from Fife Constabulary are carrying out an investigation following the discovery of a man's body in Dunfermline.

item.title: Controlled explosion on pipe bomb
item.description: Army bomb experts carry out a controlled explosion on a pipe bomb-type device found in Newry.

item.title: Van hijacked during town trouble
item.description: There are more disturbances near Lurgan, County Armagh, on Thursday morning.

item.title: Murder police 'bullied' witnesses
item.description: A retired senior police officer "bullied" witnesses to give false evidence to put five innocent men on trial for murdering Cardiff prostitute Lynette White, a court hears.

item.title: Social worker failed abuse family
item.description: A social worker from the Vale of Glamorgan failed to properly warn a family about the risks posed by a teenager he was placing in their care, a disciplinary hearing finds.

item.title: Bashir blessing for South Sudan
item.description: Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir pledges his support to South Sudan, which gains its independence on Saturday, saying he wants a "secure and stable neighbour".

item.title: Somalis flee drought to Ethiopia
item.description: Somalis are fleeing to Ethiopia to escape the devastating drought at a rate of 1,600 a day, arriving at already overcrowded camps

item.title: Police end Malaysia nursery siege
item.description: Some 30 children and their teachers are safe after a man who held them hostage in their Malaysian kindergarten is arrested, police say.

item.title: Chinese longest bridge 'is safe'
item.description: The chief engineer of the world's longest sea-bridge, in China, denies allegations he rushed the construction to get it ready for last week's Communist Party anniversary.

item.title: ECB raises interest rates to 1.5%
item.description: Eurozone interest rates are raised to 1.5% in an attempt to cool inflation despite worries that weaker economies could be hit.

item.title: Dutch hurt in stadium roof fall
item.description: Part of the stadium roof collapses at the Dutch football club FC Twente, trapping up to a dozen people.

item.title: US-Mexico trucking row resolved
item.description: Mexican trucks will be allowed onto US roads, after Mexican and US officials sign a deal to implement a key trade accord after years of argument.

item.title: 'Mistakes' in US-Mexico gun sting
item.description: The head of the US firearms agency tells Congress that mistakes were made during an operation meant to track the illegal movement of guns to Mexico.

item.title: Israel 'angry' at Lebanon report
item.description: Israeli officials are reportedly boycotting a UN official in Lebanon who wrote a report criticising Israel's response to a Palestinian border protest.

item.title: Egyptians riot over police trials
item.description: Riots erupt in the Egyptian city of Suez, after a court upholds the release on bail of policemen accused of killing 17 people during the revolution.

item.title: India minister 'quits over graft'
item.description: India's Textile Minister Dayanidhi Maran resigns following allegations of involvement in the country's biggest corruption scandal, media reports say.

item.title: Indian bus collision 'kills 38'
item.description: At least 38 people were killed after a train ploughed into a bus carrying wedding guests at a level crossing in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, officials say.

item.title: Fort Hood 'shooter' to be tried
item.description: The US Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at a Texas base will be tried in a court martial, a senior officer has ruled.

item.title: Strauss-Kahn prosecutor 'to stay'
item.description: The chief prosecutor in the attempted rape trial of former IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn rejects calls to stand down.

item.title: Firms pull advertising from NoW
item.description: More companies withdraw advertising from the News of the World in light of the phone-hacking scandal.

item.title: Fuel duty 'should cut bus fares'
item.description: The government should use money from fuel duty to cut the price of public transport, according to a group of MPs.

item.title: UK manufacturing rebounds in May
item.description: UK manufacturing output jumped by the largest amount in a year during May, figures show, rebounding from a sharp drop in April.

item.title: PM 'too slow' over hack inquiry
item.description: Labour leader Ed Miliband accuses David Cameron of failing "to react with the necessary speed" to the phone hacking scandal and demands he set up an inquiry now.

item.title: Stop police bail bill say lawyers
item.description: Top lawyers sign an open letter urging the government to halt its emergency police bail bill.

item.title: More info to go public - minister
item.description: The government pledges a "quantum leap in transparency" - with plans for more information on schools, hospitals, GPs and the courts to be published.

item.title: North-South heart death 'divide'
item.description: Deaths through heart disease are highest in the north west of England, according to a survey of primary care trusts.

item.title: NHS chiefs' waiting times warning
item.description: Financial problems in the NHS are likely to cause a rise in waiting times in England, health chiefs believe, as a senior government official attacks the government's overhaul of the service.

item.title: Non-invasive embryo gene screen
item.description: Fertility doctors say they have found a new, non-invasive way to screen IVF embryos for genetic abnormalities.

item.title: Funds 'push schools into phonics'
item.description: An MPs' committee says schools in England are being given financial incentives by the government to use certain approved phonics materials in the teaching of reading.

item.title: School lunches take-up increases
item.description: Take-up of school lunches in England rises, with recent increases now compensating for a drop in the wake of TV chef Jamie Oliver's campaign, data suggests.

item.title: Sats marks rile hundreds of heads
item.description: More than 300 heads in England have lodged concerns with the National Association of Head Teachers over some of this year's national curriculum tests, known as Sats.

item.title: Facebook adds in Skype video chat
item.description: Facebook announces a partnership with Skype to add a video chat service to the social networking site, a week after Google launched a similar feature.

item.title: Free airwaves for rural broadband
item.description: Rural broadband speeds could get a boost as the government considers using gaps in radio spectrum to bring faster net services to outlying areas.

item.title: Illegal film downloads 'up 30%'
item.description: The number of illegally downloaded films in the UK goes up nearly 30% in five years, new figures seen by Newsbeat suggest.

item.title: Chimp recognises synthetic speech
item.description: A chimpanzee can recognise distorted words spoken by a computer, suggesting apes are more capable of perceiving speech than previously thought.

item.title: Weather looks worse for shuttle
item.description: Weather remains the primary concern ahead of Friday's planned launch of the last shuttle mission, with the forecast deteriorating to a 70% chance of "no-go" conditions.

item.title: MEPs back national GM crop bans
item.description: Euro MPs vote to give governments more room to restrict or ban genetically modified crops.

item.title: Guardi work sets Venice benchmark
item.description: A view of Venice by the 18th Century painter Francesco Guardi fetches more money at auction than any other painting depicting the Italian city.

item.title: Homophobia row opera to go ahead
item.description: An opera by Billy Elliot creator Lee Hall, which was at the centre of a dispute over a gay character, is to go ahead after amendments to the script.

item.title: Wood wins brace of radio awards
item.description: Rolling Stone Ronnie Wood wins two prizes at the Arqiva Commercial Radio awards, while David 'Kid' Jensen gets a lifetime honour.

item.title: Who are the squatters?
item.description: For many people, the word squatter conjures up the image of a dreadlocked, middle-class, tree-hugging hippie. But is this a myth?

item.title: Is phone hacking still possible?
item.description: The phone hacking scandal came to light five years ago. But as the list of victims grows, are mobile phones any safer today?

item.title: Three royal women and their dresses
item.description: All eyes have been on the Duchess of Cambridge's outfits on her first overseas tour as a royal wife. Do queens and princesses let their clothes do the talking?

item.title: VIDEO: Live: Police (Detention and Bail) Bill
item.description: Peers are debating emergency legislation to reverse a legal ruling that restricts the use of police bail in England and Wales.

item.title: Test tube miracles
item.description: 25 years of IVF treatment at one of the UK's first dedicated centres

item.title: VIDEO: Harry Potter stars through the years
item.description: With the premiere of the final Harry Potter film taking place on Thursday, BBC News looks back at how the saga's three young stars have grown up on the red carpet.

item.title: VIDEO: First glimpse of puffins feeding young
item.description: Special cameras have been installed on an island off the north-east coast of England to record the subterranean life of puffins.

item.title: VIDEO: Cable car flies over Rio slum
item.description: The cable car ride should take around 16 minutes to cover 6 stops, saving residents hours of walking and bus rides.

item.title: VIDEO: 'My life working on spacecraft'
item.description: Only one flight remains before the space shuttle programme's 30-year history comes to an end.

item.title: VIDEO: Royals visit town devastated by fires
item.description: The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are continuing their tour of North America. The Canadian leg of the trip is drawing to a close.

item.title: VIDEO: Japan's hot spring energy solution
item.description: Japan has long talked about renewable energy, but what was once a luxury has now become an urgent necessity.

item.title: VIDEO: Brothers who unicycle to school
item.description: Three brothers from Greater Manchester travel to school in a rather unusual way - by unicyle.

item.title: VIDEO: Clapping protesters 'arrested' in Belarus
item.description: Human rights groups in Belarus say the authorities have arrested more than 200 people for taking part in street protests against President Aleksander Lukashenko.

item.title: Decoding labels
item.description: How can you work out what is in food?

item.title: In pictures
item.description: Celebrating Hollywood's golden era

item.title: Kentish scene
item.description: What defines England's national identity?

item.title: Ladybird watch
item.description: Red ones, black ones, yellow ones - what's the difference?

item.title: Bizarre link
item.description: Does Wimbledon affect washing machine repairs?

item.title: In pictures
item.description: Three decades of the space shuttle as final flight nears

item.title: Silverstone supreme
item.description: Mark Webber blogs on this weekend's British GP

item.title: Face to face
item.description: Is video chat the killer app for social networks?
